For example, a person can start working there at a base rate based on their experience when they start. Now fast forward five years down the line, that person pay is still the same, but here comes a new hire that has a little bit more experience than you had when you started and they're making more than you. Now because the base pay for new hire have increased a person with 6 months experience check is more than yours with 5 years' experience and that isn't right or fair, hence why so many employees left. The salary wasn't worth getting a vaccine that no one is 100% sure about. A lot of people stayed because they been there so long what's the point of starting over when you are not sure how a new job with be any better. It like that old saying "better the devil you know"! devil that you know

review_title: I Worked At UTMB for Approximately 13 Years But Had To Leave Campus To Get a Promotion
pros:
Decent benefits
Better salary since I moved off the Island
cons: Administration stubbornly will not promote from within the department. The choice jobs are reserved for friends and favorites. Shining star multitaskers are purposefully kept down to perform  all the menial, tedious grind  jobs that management thinks are below them. Raises are for upper management.

review_title: UTMB, it's one of a kind
pros: Working for UTMB is like working for the government, or a university, in a small town and it's also like working for a start up.    It is an exciting time at UTMB, lots of growth and change.   Great people, great vision, great benefits. You can determine your path within the UT system and you will be supported on that path.
cons: With change comes...change. New people come in who share a similar vision and others move on who don't.  There are growing pains as new systems and processes are created.  Being flexible is essential as well as not losing sight of the main goal which is to provide quality healthcare services. Also, it's important not to forget that everyone on every level is important and is on the same team.

pros:
Treated well, especially for a resident.  Great pathology of patients.   Believe it or not, the prison hospital was an interesting place to be.  You have to be VERY ill to be admitted.   I was able to see pathology that you usually do not see in the community. 
MD Anderson was the opposite side of the spectrum in terms of patient demographics. 
Living on an island.
Unable to have a phone during prison clinic.   I needed to petition the warden.
Also as a female, I kept on getting padded down daily by a grumpy female guard.  This irked me because I could not keep up with my peers, who are all Caucasian and Asian. They did not get searched at all.   I am not looking for a boyfriend in the prison.
cons: travel time, opportunities for fellowship.  It is a great place for residency.  When you go to a hospital with many fellows as a resident, basically you do scut.

review_title: I QUIT My Job of 37 Years
pros:
The Group Benefits are pretty good.
Training offered for all the business process software you will be expected to master.
Starting salary is competitive.
cons:
Most of the buildings are old and need new carpet flooring or paint.  Some were  hit hard by the hurricane so they are very much in need of repair and upkeep.
Parking either costs too much, is too crowded or inconvenient.
Department management does not care about their staff.  The rule of thought is "you can be replaced."  No focus on retaining already trained staff with longevity and that costs the University real time, effort and money.

review_title: If  I could give this place zero stars, I would...
pros: The benefits are the only reason people stay here, but it's not even worth that
cons: Management is terrible, lazy and is very clearly only there for the money & retirement. The work environment is awful. Employees that kiss butt exceed & get raises, the hard working employees get zero recognition. Essentially, all you get as a hard working employee, is taking on other people's work. There are so many politics going on here, it's a nightmare. They send you to offices all over the place, even when you were hired for only one office. The wait time at some offices is HOURS, which makes for a very stressful environment for patients & employees. There are physicians that work here that are TERRIBLE, and have made huge mistakes, yet UTMB continues to allow them to work there out of desperation. I honestly can't say enough. I would never recommend anyone work here, or come here as a patient. There's some seriously dirty politics going on here. Oh, and good luck ever getting to use your PTO. The company has skimmed the employees so thin, you can't even get it approved.

pros: Great benefits. A 110+ year old hospital that's well-known in the area and rapidly expanding across South & East Texas. If I tell friends and family I work at UTMB I get complimented, but only if they've never worked for UTMB or never received care from them.
cons:
Weak performance from hospital staff and administration. Nurses are under-educated, as the "fast-track program" either seems to be too weak on the curriculum or the curriculum just isn't good. When talking with affiliates and customers who go to UTMB for care, or as a care provider, 8/10 times they have negative feedback regarding the nursing staff. Dr's and administration staff are incredibly over-paid for the quality and amount of work that's being done.
Low Quality Employees
Aloof Senior Staff
Lackadaisical/Ignorant Management (this can't be expressed enough)

review_title: Great benefits, superior care, amazing staff
job_title: Correctional Health Care Staff Member in Galveston, TX
pros: Benefits, ability to grow within my expertise, great auxiliary staff, superior and wide-ranging health care, great employee-based support system, good leadership, caring and attentive president
cons: Compensation in my position is well below the national median for the same job.  Poor performers are not reprimanded quickly enough, which is a result of a "trigger-shy" human resources department, which is a result of past issues with improper or poorly documented disciplinary action.  So, it's essentially the responsibility of mid-level supervisors to accurately identify and relay performance problems upwards and through HR.  I see episodes of incompetence at several levels of care and administration, but that's common to any large institution.

job_title: Police Officer II in Galveston, TX
pros:
Training: UTMB's Police Department will send you (with a stipend and housing paid) to the UT System Police Academy if you are hired as a Police Cadet.  After graduation, they have an extensive OJT Field Officer Training program and internal continuing education program.
Specialty:  There is a bicycle patrol option, though there are a limited number of positions.

Pay: Well above norms for the field with annual review cycle that allows for pay increases based on performance rather than all staff getting the same raise.
Benefits: Excellent medical coverage (100% paid by department), optional dental, vision, short and long term disability...  403b, tuition assistance
cons: If your desire is to be on SWAT, do undercover work, etc, then this is not the right position for you.

job_title: Financial Analyst, Level II in Galveston, TX

cons:
Mid level management has high demands from their employees, but has not developed any meaningful means to train employees not familiar with the institutions software.  There is also a 6 month probationary period used to cull positions once their Annual Financial Report is complete or near completion.

Due to depreciation of the new hospital, the 2 year outlook is grim.  I would hesitate before taking a job here as every position is expendable until they have depreciated much of the cost of the Jenny Seally Building off the books.

pros: There is definitely opportunity for advancement.  The organization is growing and it is a great place to begin your career.  The benefits are excellent.  I have grown and learned a great deal about the business over the past few years.
cons: The salary get a good salary upon entry because once you're hired it is hard to increase your salary unless you move around or leave and come back.  There is a great deal of red tape and sometimes takes forever to get things done.

pros: Best coworkers and student population I have ever worked with.  Autonomy to do your job, no micromanaging.  Lots of support to do your job.  Team environment, positive and professional.  Kindness and good intentions.

job_title: Nurse Clinician I in Huntsville, TX
pros: Great schedule with a healthy amount of time off. Excellent benefits starting the day you begin. Challenging work. I have met and worked with some wonderful people. Beautiful University and Hospital campus, and a sense of pride each time I say that, "I work for UTMB".
cons: I work in the Correctional Managed Care aspect of UTMB. My workplace is a healthcare facility within the confines of a men's state prison. Its absolutely interesting, however it is also dangerous. As a woman, I am subjected daily to lecherous behavior by many of the inmates. I had expected more order, but a blind eye is often turned towards the sexual harassment. Lastly, turnover. It is high here.

job_title: Diagnostic Medical Sonographer in Galveston, TX
pros: Amazing benefits.  Very affordable health, dental and vision insurance.  The supplemental retirement accounts are a huge plus.
cons: Call, Texas Department of Corrections and reluctance to pay overtime, especially on call backs on holidays.  If you don't work 40 hours, you get paid straight time.  And they always find a way to get your hours down to 40.  Taking call for seven straight days is brutal when completing your regular shift as well. Unscheduled absences are held against employees, even when work has been completed for the day and a family emergency pops up.

review_title: My experience working here was not a good one.
pros: Cost of living raises are given annually, based on employee performance evaluation scores. Benefits and retirement package are very good. They have a great gym and pool for students and employees.
cons: Promotions are not given for merit, dedication, or knowledge. Most promotions are given for seniority and/or favoritism. Some managers are friends with subordinates and all employees aren't held to the same set of rules. There's not enough communication between clinical areas, causing animosity & rudeness between staff. Many departments stay chronically understaffed. Oh, and every few years there's a large layoff.

pros: Pros would be decent compensation.  You have quite a few paid holidays throughout the year, plus paid sick time and vacation..  They pay for your medical insurance, so you only have to pay for anyone else in your family that you add on.
cons: When I was first hired, I was hired as a contractor, so I was not eligible for benefits.  My contact only lasted for a few months before I was brought on full-time, but some employees stay contract for years and never are given benefits and paid holidays.

review_title: Be wary if faculty being recruited as faculty to UTMB. Look at retention rates.
pros:
I liked my colleagues, but many left over time.

Work life balance and flexibilty has been outstanding.
cons:
The university is overall not that supportive of research. UTMB has dropped several points in procuring  NIH finding over the past several years.

The faculty do not get COLA or annual cost of living raises like everyone else. It appears compensation and bonuses are more based on politics and nepitism. Salary pay rate is below market value for the majority. A select few do really well.

Be wary of faculty compensation plan. The university can adjust salary downward if you do need meet high expectations and benchmarks. The rules are not transparent and have not applied equally or fairly across everyone. Leadership hired an outside firm to look into it. They recieved feedback and seem to be doing little to fix the problem. Meanwhile, faculty lives and livlihood have been effective and faculty have been forced to leave because once the salary is reduced, it is impossible to dig yourself out of the hole it creates and get back to market value. I have witnessed awesome faculty leave in all areas teaching, clinical, and research. This includes superstars or rising stars with NIH funding or great physicians because of low compensation, not recieving promotion or tenure, not feeling supported. I have personally witnessed several colleagues go on to other highly ranked universitites and get automatic promotion and significantly higher salary after being denied promotion at UTMB. Something is wrong. I believe it was both. University issue as well as department issue.

Very little opportunity for advancement.

Junior faculty will find a sink or swim atmosphere. Very little support. For researchers, it is hard to survive unless you are able to bring in your own grant funding. The resources that do exist (ITS, core facilities, institutional grants) appear to support a select few of the “in crowd” and do not do what intended by supporting junior faculty researchers to support their research. They bring in new trainees (through T32 and KL2) and then have high turnover because little support for helping them succeed and advance.

review_title: It had some nice people but wasn't all that I expected
pros: Pay, benefits, new bldg, parking
cons: First year on rotating shift as needed, not a set rotation. Evaluation program is like having a second job, takes up alot of personal time to complete, could have better training program, was told alot of things in the interview that were an exaggeration of the truth about the atmosphere of the unit. Maybe the manager just didn't know how disgruntled the employees were but I was made know with in the first couple hours of working.

pros: Work from Home. Have great medical benefits, retirement.
cons: Work Mandatory OT. Never get anytime off...

pros: Competitive Salaries and great health benefits - if you need to get into a doctor, you have first priority - and typically can get in to see UTMB docs on the same day.  Working hours are working hours - 40 a week - typically no more. Great work-life balance... not even discussed because it is so good.
cons: Everything moves SLOW - all decisions - due to multiple committee approvals being required. Can be very political - all is driven from the top down, very little decisions making at the lower levels.

pros: Salary; benefits (if you need them); training (CPR) and other support provided to new hires; new employee orientation was a very  nice touch, although the benefits were pretty overwhelming and I would of liked more assistance with getting that set up.
cons: NO flexibility; lost my work/life balance; rigid bureaucracy with policy after policy;  if you're not used to this, it may be too difficult to start; exempt employees are expected to clock-in/out and work longer than 40 hours; expectations not clear (have to drive my own car to make bank deposit runs daily with no reimbursements); promised bilingual pay/opportunity but they have a company doing it and no one is passing (that wasn't made clear in the negotiating process!); crappy dress code; old equipment/software (my programs are more than 15 years old and so there is no tech support); sorry keyboard and computers are ancient; no one uses software programs/outlook to coordinate meetings (drop-ins without appts are common to discuss important items) and the list goes on.  Bad fit or picture wasn't painted properly?  computer system for patient registration is ridiculous.  any system that takes employees 2 months to fully learn needs reconsidering;  timekeeping is a chore and confusing to even the employees;  Primates used in research experiments/ how shameful since the CDC came out two years ago saying it's unnecessary to continue to do that to animals.  Get with the modern century and lead the way with a human conscious and don't try to sell us cruelty in company emails that say "it's always been done".

pros:
Competitive salary
Fair Benefits
Free parking for Physicians
cons:
The hospital is our home base but the department office space is in poor condition.

pros: UTMB benefits are hard to beat.   Your work  experience will largely depend on what your  job title is and who you work for. At best you will find a pleasant experience where expectations are reasonable and job pressures are low.
